reviewText: Charmed is the story of three sisters who after their grandmother dies discovers they are witches with enormous powers chosen by destiny to fight evil and protect the innocent. Yes the show is just as cheesy as it sounds, but it manages to pull it off with style. Charmed is funny, exiting and have large amounts of drama and a hint of horror. The Halliwell sisters live in an old villa in San Fransisco, they come together when their youngest sister Phoebe comes back home after getting into trouble in New York, this results in the sisters receiving their birthright, magical powers, and becoming the Charmed Ones, witches destines to protect the world from the forces of evil. To aid them they have their family Book of Shadows, a sort of spellbook, and a guardian angel. In addition to magic and monsters the Halliwell sisters have to deal with problems in their personal lives, and problems between them as the three of them could not be more different.In the first season the setting is established, the characters are introduced. As the series progress more of an overarching storyline starts to form but in season one it is very much monster of the week. The episodes are usually built up around the sisters discovering some supernatural evil, doing a spell to stop it, figuring out it did not work, scramble around for another one and finally saving the day, and they do this all the while wearing the most exquisite outfits, and trying to sort out their rather complicated personal lives. This series is pure fantasy, it is a perfect way to relax and let your mind drift.I think Charmed fit all audiences, it is not scary enough to not be suitable for younger audiences (especially the first season, the show do get darker in later seasons) while at the same time having enough omph! to entertain adults. Fans of Buffy the Vampire slayers should definitely check this out as the two shows are rather similar. I can not really think of much to say about this show, as it is rather simple in concept really ridiculously good looking people fight supernatural evil with magic, all I can say is that it is really, really good and recommend that you give it a try.I have two complaints about this show however, one is the constant reference to Wicca, basically presenting Wicca as just another word for witchcraft. What the characters in this series do is not Wicca, they do fantasy witchcraft, Wicca is a specific religion. My other complaint is that the series at times can get a bit to goodie goodie, at times the no personal gains rules of good magic in the setting is ridiculously strict, while at other times it do not seam to apply at all. However this is just minor complaints, Charmed is a great show, I highly recommend it and season 1 is a great opening season. This DVD set contains hours of amazing entertainment!

reviewText: On the surface, "Charmed" looks very much like one of my all-time favorite television shows, "Buffy the Vampire Slayer". Both programs share a cast of supporting characters that includes witches, demons, and other beasties that go bump in the night. But beyond the surficial similarities, these two series couldn't be more different.  The subtext of BtVS is about life and relationships. Despite the low-budget special effects, BtVS is brilliantly written and never, never dumbs down for its audience.I expected something similar from "Charmed". What I found was, there is no subtext. What you see onscreen, witches, demons, etc, is what this show is about; there is no depth to it.  From the first five minutes, through the first few episodes, I found the show to be peculiarly charmless.  At first, I thought the problem was the three stars: perhaps they couldn't act. After a few episodes, I realized they have nothing to work with. The fault lies with the scripts.  It's a shame, too.  As BtVS has proven, there is great potential in a show like this, but without a decent script, the entire exercise becomes pointless. So, too, does watching it.

reviewText: As a loyal fan of the Sisters Halliwell, the long-overdue release of the boxed set "Charmed - The Complete First Season" is a great pleasure!Beginning with the discovery of their magical abilities, the first season wisely avoided "Buffy" comparisons by focusing, instead, on the efforts of the three sisters to combine "The Power of Three" with some semblance of a 'normal' life. Thus, eldest sister, Prue (the tempermental and ultimately 'short-lived' sibling, Shannen Doherty) juggles appraising antiquites, a sporadic affair with Homicide detective Andy Trudeau (T.W. King), and serving as a mentor to her younger sisters, while shy, introverted Piper (Holly Marie Combs) combines her talents as a chef with managing the trendy bistro, "Quake", and experiences a growing attraction to a handyman with a 'secret', Leo (Brian Krause). Only the youngest sister, free-spirited Phoebe (Alyssa Milano) shuns a regular job, devoting herself to exploring the sisters' mystical guidebook, the "Book of Shadows", and learning of their mystical heritage.For those more familiar with the flashier, occasionally silly storylines of later seasons, the first 22 episodes may come as quite a surprise; each episode is carefully crafted, offers some excellent acting, and is often quite compelling. While Piper's droll timing and sarcastic one-liners (a major reason for the series' continuing success) are seldom evident in the first season, the incredible chemistry between her and Leo is ever-present, and far more interesting than the Prue/Andy romance, a fact not lost on the writers (Andy would be gone by season's end, while the door was wisely 'left open' to allow Leo an increasingly important role in the Halliwell's lives). Other regulars of the "Charmed" 'universe' are also introduced, including Andy's partner, the long-suffering Inspector Darryl Morris (Dorian Gregory); wise and funny 'Grams' Halliwell (the delightful Jennifer Rhodes); the sisters' mother, Patty (Finola Hughes), and father, Victor (portrayed in the first season by "Crime Story" alum, Tony Denison, and replaced by James Read in subsequent seasons).The rapport between the three leading actresses is warm, genuine, and unforced, with no hint of the future on-set rivalries between Doherty and Milano that would create headlines by Season Three (and would lead to Doherty 'walking off' the show). Season One, in fact, includes one of Doherty's best "Charmed" performances, as three variations of herself, in the wryly funny "Which Prue Is It, Anyway?" While some male fans may be disappointed in Phoebe's less-revealing outfits in the first season, she was never cuter, or sweeter, than in these first 22 episodes."Charmed" has had many memorable moments over it's seven-year run, and certainly deserves boxed sets of each season; whether you have followed the series from the first episode, or are catching up, Season One is well worth a place in your DVD collection (although some 'bonus' materials would have been a welcome addition to the set).Experience "The Power of Three" from the beginning...you'll be glad you did!
summary: Magical First Season of "Charmed Ones" a Winner!

reviewText: Granted, with the success of witch shows -- born of Bewitched, no doubt, which was a great series in every respect -- and especially the Buffy series, which should be required watching for anyone aiming at a career in film or TV -- granted, there would be a number of knockoffs on commercial TV.  The excellent script writing, directing, film editing, and every other facet of film/TV making, is well displayed, in both series.  Hollywood knows well, that one should ape success.What made both series great, was the blending of many geniuses, all held together by a script rich in the study of pagan religion, and unafraid to make fun of itself, of the genre;  eager, to allude to many another play, song, poem, TV show or ancient myth, in campy satire.So too granted, the Wicca craze makes any series on that topic, popular;  granted, famous child actresses who lead the Charmed cast would make people watch, even if only out of curiosity;  but even such actresses, given horrible script, bad direction and worse story lines, can't save a series.So the fact that this series lasted 8 seasons, is beyond me.  I had to force myself to watch the entire first season on Amazon Instant Video, hoping somewhere the script and storyline would find its legs.  But it didn't.  The last few episodes were a tad less shallow, with some nice moments.. but I was relieved to find out that the succeeding seasons were not free.  That gave me my excuse to stop watching.There is absolutely no ensemble chemistry, except for 'Leo';  he had presence, a vital requirement for screen acting.  In his resurrection scene with 'Piper', there was chemistry.  But none, between the sisters.  None, between 'Pru' and 'Andy'.  Very little character development, despite a script that consciously tried to build it.  And you knew that was what the script 'tried' to do.  Warning, would-be scriptwriters:  when your audience becomes aware of the script and its role, you got a bad script.  Kinda like, explaining a joke.  I half expected to see chalk marks on the floor, to show the blocking.While the series aired live on television, I had only seen glimpses of some of the later seasons, but couldn't bear watching for more than 10-15 minutes, taking a break.  Now I know why.First, the storyline is syrupy, for teenyboppers.  Second, it's shallow, every episode about someone who wants to take away 'the Charmed Ones' prophetically-predicted powers, which they themselves had forgotten, until their witch grandmother died.  Third, the humor is flat, the lines are wooden, spoken by actresses who proved themselves capable in other shows.  So it must be that they were directed, to be hollow.  May as well have been reading cue cards.  Packaged lines, packaged plot, neatly ending when the episode ends, no surprises.  One exception: the last episode, the guy playing the demon who had Groundhog day until he could get it right, and never did.  He had panache.Oh, the demon makeup, special effects?  Awful.  Had the show been aiming at camp, it would have been better, but the storyline pretended to be serious or light.  Oh, see the good witches always sacrificing themselves to save someone else, using cheap magic tricks always with a happy ending, even when someone dies.Blech.

They have been living there, taking care of their grandmother, PENELOPE "PENNY" HALLIWELL (played by Jennifer Rhodes), who had been sick for awhile. Moving in with Prue and Piper is their sister, PHOEBE HALLIWELL (played by the sexy knock-out, Alyssa Milano). I should mention that Prue is the oldest of the sisters, with Piper being the 2nd oldest, and Phoebe being the baby. Below is the episode list."Something Wicca This Way Comes"Phoebe returns to live with her older sisters, Prue and Piper, and finds a book of witchcraft in the attic. After reciting an incantation, they gain the supernatural powers they were destined to have."I've Got You Under My Skin"Piper has trouble dealing with her power while Phoebe meets a photographer who is sucking the life out of young women to maintain his youth."Thank You for Not Morphing"The sisters' estranged father returns, but trouble arises when he teams up with the new neighbors, who are more than what they seem."Dead Man Dating"Piper falls for the ghost of a recently murdered man who needs her help. Phoebe gets a job as a hotel psychic to pay for Prue's birthday present."Dream Sorcerer"Prue finds her sleep disturbed by strange visions in which she's taunted by a man. Meanwhile Phoebe and Piper cast a spell to attract men which goes awry."The Wedding from Hell"The sisters must face Hecate, a powerful demon goddess, who is attempting to conceive a full demon child."The Fourth Sister"A troubled teenage girl who has been manipulated by an evil sorceress befriends Phoebe with the hopes of joining the Halliwells."The Truth Is Out There...and It Hurts"The sisters race to stop a mysterious killer while Prue uses a truth spell on Andy."The Witch Is Back"A warlock from the past is released from his curse and tries to steal the sisters' powers, but the sisters resurrect their ancestor to combat him."Wicca Envy"When Prue is framed by Rex for stealing from the auction house, it's up to Piper and Phoebe to save her and uncover the truth."Feats of Clay"When Phoebe's ex-boyfriend comes to town he brings trouble in the forum of a stolen Egyptian urn which carries a mortal curse."The Wendigo"When Piper is attacked by a vicious beast, Andy goes on a stakeout with an FBI agent who is hunting the creature."From Fear to Eternity"The sisters' mother warns them about a demon from the underworld who comes around every 1300 years on Friday the 13th to literally scare witches to death and feed on their fear."Secrets and Guys"Prue helps a young witch who has been kidnapped, and renews her own faith in having children. Meanwhile, Phoebe finds out that Leo is really a guardian angel, causing him to break up with Piper."Is There A Woogy In The House?"An earthquake releases a shadow demon, "the Woogyman". Phoebe, under his control, tries to kill Prue and Piper, who must find a way to rescue Phoebe and vanquish the demon."Which Prue Is It, Anyway?"When Phoebe has a premonition of Prue being stabbed to death, it coincides with a warrior coming to town in order to kill the eldest sibling witch as he did to the sisters' great-great-great-aunt. reviewText: Charmed could have easily been a simple television retread of The Craft. Instead, it has become, over the years and seven seasons later, a positive representation of smart, beautiful, empowered women. The show quickly dispels the traditional image of witches as evil, old hags dressed in black and riding broomsticks and presents them as contemporary women who tap into Mother Nature and fight for the forces of good. Charmed also treats the Wicca religion with the proper amount of respect that it deserves.Perhaps the most disappointing aspect of this set is the appalling lack of extras. With such a devoted fan base that has waited so long for DVDs of this show to finally come out, the surprising lack of extras is a real slap in the face. No trailers, featurettes, or commentaries. Nothing. The folks at Paramount really need to study the work Fox has done on their TV shows (especially Angel and Buffy) to see how it's done and to support the show's loyal fans.

reviewText: I'm sorry.I am. I wanted to like this show. After all, it is about interesting things--witches and the supernatural are kind of cool. Also, it stars three very beautiful women, and being a guy as I am, I happen to love watching very beautiful women. More than that, my favorite show of all time is Buffy the Vampire Slayer. I had heard from some that Charmed is "kind of like Buffy the Vampire Slayer..."Well, I think that Charmed is kind of like Buffy the Vampire Slayer in the same way that Shakespeare is kind of like Troma Productions. Sure, they both create stories with heroes and villains. They both have romance and lots of action. But there are also some differences between Shakespeare and Troma, the most important being: quality.Similarly, the biggest difference between Charmed and Buffy the Vampire Slayer is quality. Buffy the Vampire Slayer (BtVS) is a high-quality show because of its witty dialogue, wonderful characters and suspenseful plots; Buffy also succeeds in being smart in a literary sense, and has drawn much acclaim for its intellectual merit, as well. Charmed feels like its scripts might have been written in crayon.Everything in Charmed is utterly contrived. The dialouge is almost completely expository. Also, things simply don't make sense.Consider: the sisters (the stars of the program) discover this ancient book (written in the late seventeenth century) and find that it is written in modern English. When they summon forth their ancestor from that same time, she also speaks in modern English.Why? No explanation. The characters don't even find it strange. They just accept it, because...?Consider: there is a supernatural entity sworn to watch over these sisters but never let them know of his mystical abilities/origins. They accidentally discover his secret when he uses his magic powers to change a light bulb. Midday. In their living room. While one of them is in the next room.Now, come on. If he was trying to hide his powers from the sisters, why would he use them to change a light bulb. Midday. In their living room. While one of them is in the next room.?Again, no explanation. No... nothing. It's as though the writers don't expect the shows viewers to ask any questions.Consider: They fight an enemy whose power is that he can convince anyone to do practically anything through some sort of "astral projection." He can even convince them that they've seen things they haven't. He watches the sisters for weeks, plotting and planning, insinuating himself in their lives. His grand scheme for victory? He's going to frame one of the sisters for theft and blackmail her out of her birthright powers.What? That's his big plan? This villain can make them believe anything he wants them to believe; he can make them do anything he wants them to do. And... his scheme is to frame one of them for theft and then blackmail them?One of the worst things about the show is that the sisters almost always win in the end because one of their secret powers is seeing the future. That's right--instead of having to solve mysteries (like in BtVS), they just "see" who the bad guy is, or what's going to happen, or where it's going to happen... and then they go there and beat up the bad guy.And that brings up the morality. Morality on BtVS is almost always shades of grey. Even the worst of villains usually have some redeeming values, some humanity. Here, the philosophy of the show is juvenile at best. The sisters are "good witches"... because. They are. And there are evil warlocks for much the same reason. Characters don't have motivation beyond "being good" or "being evil" and that seems to be a by-product of birth. Undoubtedly in order to seem "progressive" or "empowering" or something, the sisters are incredibly promiscuous, shacking up with a string of men who are only differentiated by having different professions and (sometimes) hair colors. Otherwise, they're the same guy.The direction of the show is just there, not really adding anything (Unlike BtVS' direction under Joss 'God' Whedon); there's no particular style to speak of. The plots aren't surprising or innovative and often times feel just sort of tacked on while the sisters deal with typical WB-style angst. The acting runs from decent to good, but the material is so poor that sometimes you can't even discern it.And so, I guess I'm trying to say that Charmed isn't very good. While the women are hot, there are many other shows that accomplish that while also serving up good, interesting, intelligent stories. In conclusion, if you haven't already, you can look towards Buffy the Vampire Slayer for those things--Shakespeare to Charmed's Troma--which accomplishes everything Charmed can't.
summary: Kind Of Like Buffy the Vampire Slayer (Except For One Thing...) *SPOILERS*

reviewText: While I give this show five stars overall, I gave this season a lower rating because it is not my favorite, and  I am continually disappointed everytime I watch the DVDs.As a long-time Charmed fanatic, I eagerly awaited the release of the DVDs, seeing as how my video tapes were getting a bit worn out. reviewText: Inspired by the actual Earth-centered religion of Wicca, many television viewers in 1998 became enchanted with the fictional story of three extraordinary sisters who, after their grandmother's death, discover that they are witches and that each has a unique magical power.  The oldest, Prudence "Prue" Halliwell (Shannen Doherty), discovers that she has a magical "punch" with which she can physically force anyone (or anything) to be thrown away from her.  The middle sister, Piper Halliwell (Holly Marie Combs), discovers that she can magically freeze anyone or anything.  The youngest sister, Phoebe Halliwell (Alyssa Milano), discovers that she has a magical gift of foresight that allows her to see potentially disastrous future events for individuals if she touches an object that has been handled by them.  As it turns out, the sisters' mother Patty Halliwell (regular guest Finola Hughes) and their grandmother Penny 'Grams' Halliwell (regular guest Jennifer Rhodes) were also witches and hidden within their San Francisco house attic is their famed Book of Shadows (book of spells and information about various paranormal beings, such as demons and white lighters).  The sisters also discover that they are unique among witches in that they possess the very powerful ability to invoke the "power of three", which is a very powerful incantation that can be used to destroy demons and other evil beings.  In fact, that is their mission: to protect the world from the evil attacks of various demons, warlocks and other evil beings.  Of course, these newly discovered abilities and frequent attacks from demons wreak havoc for the sisters' lives, especially their careers and attempts at dating.  However, the sisters also discover that they are not alone in their efforts as they are frequently visited by the ghosts of their mother and grandmother, and that the equivalent of a guardian angel known as a "white lighter", Leo Watts (Brian Krause), not only provides them with important information and assistance, he can also heal them of their wounds.  The sisters are also occasionally visited by their estranged father, Victor Bennett (regular guest James Read); and because the sisters are so frequently involved with seemingly criminal activities, they become friends with local police officer Darryl Morris (Dorian Gregory).The 22 episodes of the first season include: "Something Wicca Comes This Way", "I've Got You Under My Skin", "Thank You For Not Morphing", "Dead Man Dating", "Dream Sorcerer", "Wedding From Hell", "The Fourth Sister", "The Truth is Out There... and It Hurts", "The Witch Is Back", "Wicca Envy", "Feats of Clay", "The Wendigo", "From Fear To Eternity", "Secrets and Guys", "Is There a Woogy in the House?", "Which Prue Is It, Anyway?", "That '70s Episode", "When Bad Warlocks Go Good", "Blind Sided", "The Power of Two", "Love Hurts" and season finale "Deja Vu All Over Again".  With engaging characters, wonderful scripts, exciting plots and great special effects, I rate the first season of "Charmed" with a resounding 5 out of 5 stars and highly recommend it.  Though Shannen Doherty left "Charmed" after its third season, the show has continued to gain popularity when it included a new sister, Paige Matthews (Rose McGowan), at the beginning of the fourth season.  The seventh season of "Charmed" is currently being broadcasted.

reviewText: I jumped into this show about half a season before Shannon left and Prue along with her (trying not to spoil here for those not currently watching the show) and have been wanting to see those first three seasons or so before I first became "charmed" with the show.This DVD is no disappointment for all my years of waiting.  I am watching it almost every minute since I got it this week--cannot stop the DVD.Great show, definitely should have been released years ago!!One caveat to those wanting to take the show too literally:  DON'T.  Real wicca and real witches aren't quite like that.  This show definitely takes dramatic license.  This is not a blueprint for what witches are and what they can do--it's mostly fantasy with some truth woven in it.At the same time, those parts of the show that depict real life witches accurately do so with sensitivity and sympathy--which I like.  I especially like how the first episode discusses witchcraft and the second tackles the question about "aren't witches really evil."But this show takes a judeo-christian cosmology that real witches just don't believe in.So watch the show--buy the DVD RIGHT NOW--and then talk to real witches with kindness, respect, and reverence for the ancient knowledge they are trying to rediscover and preserve.  With "honor and reverence" as the Charmed Ones say in Prue's final Halloween episode, use this show as a jumping off point for a serious and respectful discussion about world religions.And most of all...BLESSED BE!!!

reviewText: Having missed Shannen Doherty on TV since her departure from 90210 many seasons ago, I was thrilled that she came back to doing weekly series...albeit as a witch (which I am certain must have produced many tittering in-jokes among the scripting department).Fusing Charlies Angels with Wicca traditions and a healthy dose of Bust-era feminist theory, Charmed was a big hit for the WB. This first season proves why the early years of this series really rocked.Three sisters who live together in a cool San Fransisco victorian mansion discover their lost legacy as the 'Charmed Ones' on a stormy night. The Charmed Ones are dispatched to save innocents and fight the various legions of evil.They must accomplish their missions while avoiding the scrutiny of childhood friend San Fransisco Police Department Inspector Andy Trudeau (who is deliciously played by the hunky TW King). He only knows that 'weird stuff' happens whenever Prue and/or her sisters are around.I had also vaugely remembered Alyssa Millano from her role in "Who is the Boss", but had never heard of Holly Marie Combs prior to this time. I was pleasantly suprised however, and can verify that she is my perpetual second favirote sister. Prue (Doherty) is supposed to be the eldest, but Piper (Combs) really acts as the stablizing maternal force for the group.My favirote episodes in this 22-episode season (1998-1999) are "Something wicca this way comes" which explains how three sisters become the charmed ones after Phoebe discovers the book of shadows upon a return to her childhood home.In "Thank you for not morphing" Brian Krause begins his role as Leo Wyatt, the handyman with a secret of his own, he is the charmed ones's whitelighter."That 70's episode" explains why the girls had only reccently gotten their powers back and did not remember having them as children, Finola Hughes also begins her role as the girls mother Patty Halliwell and Jennifer Rhodes who plays Penny "Grams" Haliwell made her debut in "Is there a woogy in the house".On top of everything else, this series has a really rad theme song (reprised from it's original usage in "The Craft") by Love Spit Love called "How Soon is Now". Sounding sinister in the context of that big screen release, that same music and lyrics now sound mysterious and powerful without being threatining. The Haliwell sisters are assertive and strong young women, but not evil or sadistic.I am not bothered by the lack of extras for this season release because this was the show at it's peak. Seeing this first season is an enchanting experience in it's own right.
summary: Fall under the spell of Season One

reviewText: For people new to the show "Charmed", I would recommend that they start here at Season 1. This show is really amazing in the sense that even when a story is weak in one episode, the characters and actors who portray them can make it a solid episode.Speaking of the characters, the 3 main ones start off with having no powers and you get the feeling there's a distance between them at first. Over the span of the season they go from feeling apprehensive of embracing their powers, accepting their powers but not knowing how to use them, and finally to growing stronger with them and liking being witches. Pru is the oldest of the 3 and her power of telekinesis (moving objects with her mind) is the most physically powerful, almost making her the head of the trio. Piper, the middle child, can freeze time still and grows more confidence and conviction as the series progresses. Phoebe is the youngest with the power of premonition and she starts as being a young rebellious type to becoming a more mature and family oriented woman.The relationships between the sisters are what really make this show so special. It's very cool to center it around them being witches and finding spells to vanquish demons but at the end of the day, the chemistry and the growth of the sisters is the superglue that makes this show amazing.Andy, the police officer and Pru's long-time love interest keeps things from getting too out of hand and also offers mystery with the "will they get together ever for good?". Leo, the White Lighter was a welcoming character as an angel like figure who falls in love with Piper (a love that isn't allowed). Leo also helps the sisters fight evil once his identity is revealed.This season was the first and it kept getting better as it went, even after Shannen Doherty left the show (Pru). This is definitely the place to start if you haven't seen this show before because it introduces characters that appear in later seasons and shows how everything started and how much these women change and grow under these circumstances.BUY

This season we meet Andy, Prue's ex-boyfriend from high school who's an inspector, and his partner Darryl!!! Here is Season 1:Something Wicca This Way Comes-Great episode!!! reviewText: Started with below-average SFX and sometimes laughable glitches (e.g. why do you need to open a car door for a ghost to enter the car?), it is stunning and most of all admirable to see how Charmed can evolve itself into such a good and creative series.The plot itself is 'thinner' than any comparable series (Buffy, Angel and to some extent X-file),  the lack of characters means it will be difficult to create a complicate and interwoven relationship among them.  Having said that, especially towards the end of the Season one, you will see some most creative episode in history - the last episode Deja Vu lacks any particular surprise as in a usual ending chapter but it will sure give you an memorable 45-minute.  And here, we can now be sure that Charmed will have the ability to grow into a long-term series like Buffy. Of course, the power of Charmed goes totally to the power of three - the three sisters - they are all terrific, beautiful and sexy.  Sometimes it is a pleasure just to watch them walking around in the show, and don't treatme wrong - I am referring this as an compliment.

reviewText: "Charmed" is a great show, but this is not its best season. You get the impression that the writers were still trying to figure out the tone of the show. Initially, they seem to envision it as a gritty detective drama; early episodes often feature the Charmed Ones tracking down a demonic serial killer after a string of grisly deaths. As the season progresses, the body count decreases, the tone lightens up a bit, and there's more focus on character development. By the end, the formula is perfected, setting the stage for the powerhouse second season.As for the DVD set itself: There are no extras whatsoever, and the video quality is not very good. Such a relatively recent show should not look this murky and flat; it's noticeably inferior to most TV DVDs, including subsequent "Charmed" sets.There are a number of memorable episodes in the first season of "Charmed," and I would still recommend it as a starting point, but it really only hints at how good the show would become in its second season and beyond.
summary: Shaky start to a great show; inferior video quality
